Mint should be cut for drying, says Phil
lips just when it lis in flower, and on fine
day; for if cut in damp weather. the leaves
will turn black. 1t should be tied in small
punches, and dried in a shady place out of
the wind, but to retain its natural virtues
more effectually, it has been found better to
place the mint in screen, and to dry it
quickly before fire, so that it may be pow
dered and Immediately put into glass bot
sles and kept well stopped. Parsley, thyme,
sage, and other herbs, retain their full fra
GRANGE when thus prepared. and are by this
mode secured from dust, and always ready
TO the hand of the cook.


A conserve made of mint is grateful, and
she distilled waters, both simple and spiritu-
Gus, are much esteemed. The juice Of spear
mint drank in vinegar often stops the hic-
cups. Lewis observes what Plny has be-
fore observed, that mint prevents the coag-
ulation Of milk, and hence is recommended
in milk diets. When dry, and digested IN
rectifed spirits of wine, it gives out tinc-
ture which appears by daylight of fine dark
green, but by candle light Of bright red
olour; small quantity is green BY day light
or candle light; large quantity seems i'm.
pcrvious to daylight, but when held between
the eye and the candle, OF between the eye
and the sun it appears red If put INTO fiat
bottle it appears green sidewise; but when
viewed edgewise, red.
MINT

tees for scandalizing your character, by INFORM
ing the public that you held both pew rent sub
scription and lottery money from the church,

Billy, your friend, the quandam, sends his best

! from say that you were man in public business,

what the people in England calls Paddy's garret

tain knew you when you come ts this country,
and know you still, say when you come here you
had the respectable appearance Of Spittle-feld
weaver-that your dudds was tackled on you
with more pins than buttons Billy, from your
respectabe' standing in society, we are not to
wonder at your barking like mastiH dog at any
person who should attempt to bring you to JUS
tice, but your barking is useless. l would not
give you up to proAigacy, my dear Billy, for q

NOTICE is hereby given, that the President
and Managers of the New Castle and Frenchtown
Turnpike have declared dividend for the last
six months, at the rate of six per cent. per an
mum, on the capital stock ofthe Company, which
will be paid by the Treasurer to the Stockholders
or their legal representatives, at any time after
the 95th inst.


Notice is also given that an election will be
held at the house of Bennett Lewis, in the town
Of Newt astle, on Thursday the o9tll of March,
inst, between the hours of2 and O'Clock p.
NJ. for the purpose Of choosing President, four
Managers and a Treasurer, to conduct the affairs
of the Company for the ensuing year.


JAMES COUPER, Treasr.
Newcastle, Del. March IA, 1897.
Dividend and Election.

AT WILMINGTON, DELAW hhE.


Under the superintendent and instruction of
WILLIAM SHERER, assisted by accomplished
female teachers.


The course of instruction pursued at this SEM
mary, comprises all the useful, and most OF tne
ornamental branches Of female education. Inc
daily exercises are Orthography, HEADING Wiit-
ing, Arithmetic, English Grammar, Rhetnrci
Geography and History, ancient and modern,
with constant reference to the best maps and
charts; Construction of maps; use of the Globes
Natural History; Natural Philosophy, including
Astronomy and Chemistry; Elements OF moral
| Science.
Ueekly Erercises-Biblical Recitations' Evi-
dences Of Christianity; Letter Writing ana o'h-
er species of Composition; Recaptulatlons'


| IernsS.-Board and tuition, iii any OF the tore.
going branches, sj2, so per quarter; OF, 1t PAID
| in advance, $50. Music, including the use OF
piano, s12, French, by one of the best masters,
Sc per quarter. Moderate extra charges ior
Drawing and other ornamental branches.
| The discipline of the school is mild, parental,
and christian. Particular attention IS paid not
only to the manners of the young ladies', but to
their moral and religious instruction. They are
regularly conducted to such places OF worship
and Sunday Schools, as their parents and guar
dams approve. Exercise and recreation, BENG
essential to the preservation of health and OF
mental energy, occupy the intervals OF time not
devoted to study. The institution, III all Its de-
partnents, is conducted in a manner which It
is hoped, will meet the entire appreciation OF its
patrons.

MISCELLANEOUS.

The subscribers intend to decline the Lumber
Business early this Spring, and offer their Stock
on hand at reduced prices, wholesale or retail
Any persons wishing to purchase, will find it to
their advantage to give us a call, as we have d
general assortment, consisting of Cedar and Cy-
press Shingles of various qualities; Pannel, first
and second common white pine Boards well sea-
soned; hearts Pine and Hemlock Boards; Scant-
ling and joists Of various qualities, lengths and
sizes; Poplar Plank, Boards and Scantling; plain,
speckcd and curled Maple Boards, Plank and
scantling Also, Cherry Scantling; inch and
half inch Walnut Boards, and variety of other
articles not enumerated


N. d. Any person wishing to engage in the
Lumber Business, will find it much to their ad
vantage to make application to us, as we are dis
posed to sell on reasonable terms; and the stand
is well known TO be as good as any in the Bo
rough.


EZRA HOOPES,
JOSEPH THOMAS.

To the Editor ofthe IVilmingtonian.


In your last Number, an additional lo7y
and scurrilous publication has appeared "a
gainst me. from the famous would-be Irus-
tees Of St. Peters Church, backed by the
certificate of Patrick Higgins, and the after
piece of the notorious Quack Doctor, OF or
ho8sun1 memory. That shameful production,
fraught with the most glaring falsehoods, is
degrading, and unworthy the character OF
any Trustees, and which, as a member,
much regret.


have turned those "Trustess" over to
the legal authority who have no doubt will
duly appreciate their wants, and do them
that justice their infamous deeds deserve.


My statement, by way of reply, in your
former paper, is substantially correct; and
have been, and am ready and willingt to settle
on Just and equitable terms with the church,
with any men selected who are not devoid Of
principle, but l never can condescend to
men so destitute of every principle that cha
racterizes the individuals who have so wan
tonly assailed my character.


With respect to the certificate of Patrick,
it is bundle of absurdites worthy the au-
thor He says he has known me for TWEEN
ty-6vc years, (it is true, and the only truth
he has asserted,): he has known me, and !
! have well known him to my sorrow. he eau
advert to the time and well remember, who
\ first started him in Thoroughfare Neck, and
who it was that was the loser thereby byhisir-
regular svays. and who afterwards helped
him back to Wilmington, and aided him when
without friends, or money to pay his debts or
subsist upon, and from motives of charity
gave him employ when not worth penny
Ask and reflect, does it argue well for Pat
rick to sting the hand of his 6enefactor, sad
der like" that hand which nourished and
sustained him?


Next. in order, would notice the knight
of the Bolus whose stupidity is only equalled
by his impudence in bringing into view the
name of my friend Of the city of Lancaster
whom he had induced to suppose that he
was man OF reputAtion," and had decoyed
to his residence; which, when by me dis
ccrned, for the safety Of his character anc
person called for, considering him unsafe
in the company of such a "rettile."
now take leave of the Trustees OF St
Peters Church" patrick" and his quan
dam friend, the Quack, intending on no flu
ture occasion to notice their nefarious pro-
ductions.


JVM. LARKIN.
Wilmington. March 2. 1S27.-25--4t

Loudon states, that incisions are some
times necessary to the health of the tree,
in the same manner perhaps as bleeding is
necessary for the health of the animal. The
trunk of the plum and cherry tree seldom
expand freely till longitudinal incision has
been made in the bark; and hence this OPP
Grafton is often practised by gardeners. If
she incision affects the epidermis [out side
bark only, it heals up without leaving a
scar; if it penetrates into the wood, the
wound in the wood itself never heals up com
pletely, but new wood and bark are formed
above it as before.

CURE FOR THE BITE OF A SNAKE.


As the public in the western. country are
much interested in knowing whatever may
be \ good remedy for the poison elected in
to the human hesh by the bite of snake,
think it my duty to state fact within my
own knowledge.


About the year 1915 or 1916. one of my chill
dren was bitten by copperhead, on the
inside Of both ankles, nearly at the same in
stant. l instantly produced pulverized
charcoal, and mixed 1t with as much hogs
Lard rs made it adhere. I then made plas-
ter o. it, and applied it to the wounds,
renewing the plaster every twenty or thirty
minutes. for ten or twelve hours, at the
same time giving the child fresh milk to
drink. This remedy had the desired effect
and very little pain was endured after the
application. Not more than FIVE minutes {.
lspssd from the time the child was bitten un.
From the Indiana Whig.

In performing this operation, on all plants
Of wooden texture, the essential point is to
set the roots in the ground in situation SIM
liar to that in which they we're placed, be-
fore they were taken out; not only the same
depth. but, as Mr.. Forsyth says, with the
same side to the south which was the south
side before: But as they cannot be got out
of the ground nor set again into it, with their
full length Of roots, these must be cut off
to length proportionate to their size.-
Where they are very small, let them be cut
at the length of six or eight inches, and
where they are large, double that length
or more. Let them be carefully taken up,
without breaking the roots, cutting off those
that get broken, and cutting them all off at
their proper length; and let the hole, into
which they are to be set. be sufficiently
large to receive the roots without cramping
them: Then shake in the earth gently a.
bout them, so as that each one shall retain
its proper position. AS it is difficult to give
the fbrous roots their proper place, it is
generally best to cut most of these off. In
fruit trees, all the downright roots should be
cut off.


Ifthe roots have been some time out Of
ground, it is advisable to soak them in wa
ter for eight or ten hours before they are
set in. In cold or stiff soil, they should be
set shallower. than in warm mellow one.
After they are properly bedded in the
ground, a stake should be driven in near to
each one, leaning towards them, and to these
shey should each be tied, to keep them stea-
dy; and some mulch should be laid round
she roots OF each.


In transplanting the smaller kinds, a wet
time is to be chosen, and the evening is bet
ter than any other time. AS much of the
earth should be left round the roots as pos
sible, in taking them out of the ground; ant
il they are raised with a little instrument
called gardeners trowel, by which bunch
of earth can be raised with them, they viii
be the better for it. The holes where
they are set should be we'll watered, and tn,
water should previously be well warmed by
she sun.


For the times OF transplanting different
plants, and the distances they are to be SCI
apart, see the different articles which are
the subjects of this operation.

full articles.headline: MINT
full articles.article:
Mint should be cut for drying, says Phil
lips just when it lis in flower, and on fine
day; for if cut in damp weather. the leaves
will turn black. 1t should be tied in small
punches, and dried in a shady place out of
the wind, but to retain its natural virtues
more effectually, it has been found better to
place the mint in screen, and to dry it
quickly before fire, so that it may be pow
dered and Immediately put into glass bot
sles and kept well stopped. Parsley, thyme,
sage, and other herbs, retain their full fra
GRANGE when thus prepared. and are by this
mode secured from dust, and always ready
TO the hand of the cook.


A conserve made of mint is grateful, and
she distilled waters, both simple and spiritu-
Gus, are much esteemed. The juice Of spear
mint drank in vinegar often stops the hic-
cups. Lewis observes what Plny has be-
fore observed, that mint prevents the coag-
ulation Of milk, and hence is recommended
in milk diets. When dry, and digested IN
rectifed spirits of wine, it gives out tinc-
ture which appears by daylight of fine dark
green, but by candle light Of bright red
olour; small quantity is green BY day light
or candle light; large quantity seems i'm.
pcrvious to daylight, but when held between
the eye and the candle, OF between the eye
and the sun it appears red If put INTO fiat
bottle it appears green sidewise; but when
viewed edgewise, red.

tees for scandalizing your character, by INFORM
ing the public that you held both pew rent sub
scription and lottery money from the church,
Oh, Billy, the public at large sees you dellneat-
ed in your real colours. You swore that inc
four trustees you took out writs against was Tor
leaving the state, or something to that effect
to prevent them of saying any thing more ABOUT
YOUR honest transactions with the church. You
say you will not settle with the unprncipled
trustees--you would prefer settling with some Of
the backwoodsmen, whom you could tell tuff
tale to, and wash it down with gallon OF WINS
! KEY. Billy the trustees will never ask settle
ment from you again, the law must settle 1t now.
Billy, your friend, the quandam, sends his best
respects to you in cabbage leaf, to inform you
that the people who knew you where you come
! from say that you were man in public business,
and that your habitation was an exalted one
what the people in England calls Paddy's garret
or the first story below the pavementi and
that you was not inferior in your business to any
man in Dublin to give copel polish to pair OF
boots or shoes, and the people thai you are GER
tain knew you when you come ts this country,
and know you still, say when you come here you
had the respectable appearance Of Spittle-feld
weaver-that your dudds was tackled on you
with more pins than buttons Billy, from your
respectabe' standing in society, we are not to
wonder at your barking like mastiH dog at any
person who should attempt to bring you to JUS
tice, but your barking is useless. l would not
give you up to proAigacy, my dear Billy, for q
bunch of matches. Your devoted friend,


| PURCELL
| N, p. Patrick Higgins has document Of
yours, which fully proves what you are.


March ID, 1927. 26-4tp.

full articles.headline: Dividend and Election.
full articles.article:
NOTICE is hereby given, that the President
and Managers of the New Castle and Frenchtown
Turnpike have declared dividend for the last
six months, at the rate of six per cent. per an
mum, on the capital stock ofthe Company, which
will be paid by the Treasurer to the Stockholders
or their legal representatives, at any time after
the 95th inst.


Notice is also given that an election will be
held at the house of Bennett Lewis, in the town
Of Newt astle, on Thursday the o9tll of March,
inst, between the hours of2 and O'Clock p.
NJ. for the purpose Of choosing President, four
Managers and a Treasurer, to conduct the affairs
of the Company for the ensuing year.


JAMES COUPER, Treasr.
Newcastle, Del. March IA, 1897.

full articles.headline: Young Ladies' Boarding School,
full articles.article:
AT WILMINGTON, DELAW hhE.


Under the superintendent and instruction of
WILLIAM SHERER, assisted by accomplished
female teachers.


The course of instruction pursued at this SEM
mary, comprises all the useful, and most OF tne
ornamental branches Of female education. Inc
daily exercises are Orthography, HEADING Wiit-
ing, Arithmetic, English Grammar, Rhetnrci
Geography and History, ancient and modern,
with constant reference to the best maps and
charts; Construction of maps; use of the Globes
Natural History; Natural Philosophy, including
Astronomy and Chemistry; Elements OF moral
| Science.
Ueekly Erercises-Biblical Recitations' Evi-
dences Of Christianity; Letter Writing ana o'h-
er species of Composition; Recaptulatlons'


| IernsS.-Board and tuition, iii any OF the tore.
going branches, sj2, so per quarter; OF, 1t PAID
| in advance, $50. Music, including the use OF
piano, s12, French, by one of the best masters,
Sc per quarter. Moderate extra charges ior
Drawing and other ornamental branches.
| The discipline of the school is mild, parental,
and christian. Particular attention IS paid not
only to the manners of the young ladies', but to
their moral and religious instruction. They are
regularly conducted to such places OF worship
and Sunday Schools, as their parents and guar
dams approve. Exercise and recreation, BENG
essential to the preservation of health and OF
mental energy, occupy the intervals OF time not
devoted to study. The institution, III all Its de-
partnents, is conducted in a manner which It
is hoped, will meet the entire appreciation OF its
patrons.


References. IVilmington--Rev. Z. w. Gil
bert; Hon. w. Hall; Hon. Louis M'Lane: Phita-
detphia-Rev DIR. Wilson; Rev. DR. Janeway'
Mr.. William Janvicr, Merchant, James O.
Thompson, Esq. Professor OF Languages, Uni
versity of Pennsylvania.

full articles.headline: Aumher for Sale.
full articles.article:
The subscribers intend to decline the Lumber
Business early this Spring, and offer their Stock
on hand at reduced prices, wholesale or retail
Any persons wishing to purchase, will find it to
their advantage to give us a call, as we have d
general assortment, consisting of Cedar and Cy-
press Shingles of various qualities; Pannel, first
and second common white pine Boards well sea-
soned; hearts Pine and Hemlock Boards; Scant-
ling and joists Of various qualities, lengths and
sizes; Poplar Plank, Boards and Scantling; plain,
speckcd and curled Maple Boards, Plank and
scantling Also, Cherry Scantling; inch and
half inch Walnut Boards, and variety of other
articles not enumerated


N. d. Any person wishing to engage in the
Lumber Business, will find it much to their ad
vantage to make application to us, as we are dis
posed to sell on reasonable terms; and the stand
is well known TO be as good as any in the Bo
rough.


EZRA HOOPES,
JOSEPH THOMAS.
| Wilmington, ID me. 1st, 1897. 20-tf.

full articles.headline: ADVERTISEMENT.
full articles.article:
To the Editor ofthe IVilmingtonian.


In your last Number, an additional lo7y
and scurrilous publication has appeared "a
gainst me. from the famous would-be Irus-
tees Of St. Peters Church, backed by the
certificate of Patrick Higgins, and the after
piece of the notorious Quack Doctor, OF or
ho8sun1 memory. That shameful production,
fraught with the most glaring falsehoods, is
degrading, and unworthy the character OF
any Trustees, and which, as a member,
much regret.


have turned those "Trustess" over to
the legal authority who have no doubt will
duly appreciate their wants, and do them
that justice their infamous deeds deserve.


My statement, by way of reply, in your
former paper, is substantially correct; and
have been, and am ready and willingt to settle
on Just and equitable terms with the church,
with any men selected who are not devoid Of
principle, but l never can condescend to
men so destitute of every principle that cha
racterizes the individuals who have so wan
tonly assailed my character.


With respect to the certificate of Patrick,
it is bundle of absurdites worthy the au-
thor He says he has known me for TWEEN
ty-6vc years, (it is true, and the only truth
he has asserted,): he has known me, and !
! have well known him to my sorrow. he eau
advert to the time and well remember, who
\ first started him in Thoroughfare Neck, and
who it was that was the loser thereby byhisir-
regular svays. and who afterwards helped
him back to Wilmington, and aided him when
without friends, or money to pay his debts or
subsist upon, and from motives of charity
gave him employ when not worth penny
Ask and reflect, does it argue well for Pat
rick to sting the hand of his 6enefactor, sad
der like" that hand which nourished and
sustained him?


Next. in order, would notice the knight
of the Bolus whose stupidity is only equalled
by his impudence in bringing into view the
name of my friend Of the city of Lancaster
whom he had induced to suppose that he
was man OF reputAtion," and had decoyed
to his residence; which, when by me dis
ccrned, for the safety Of his character anc
person called for, considering him unsafe
in the company of such a "rettile."
now take leave of the Trustees OF St
Peters Church" patrick" and his quan
dam friend, the Quack, intending on no flu
ture occasion to notice their nefarious pro-
ductions.


JVM. LARKIN.
Wilmington. March 2. 1S27.-25--4t

full articles.headline: INCISION IN FRUIT TREES.
full articles.article:
Loudon states, that incisions are some
times necessary to the health of the tree,
in the same manner perhaps as bleeding is
necessary for the health of the animal. The
trunk of the plum and cherry tree seldom
expand freely till longitudinal incision has
been made in the bark; and hence this OPP
Grafton is often practised by gardeners. If
she incision affects the epidermis [out side
bark only, it heals up without leaving a
scar; if it penetrates into the wood, the
wound in the wood itself never heals up com
pletely, but new wood and bark are formed
above it as before.

A PUBLIC EXHIBITION

Of ITiHiam Larkin's Msgo System oftaying


Old Debts.
full articles.article:
Cf IIItfidm Larktn'8 .Weg0 System OF faying


Old Debts.


Master Dillv, are YOU not ashamed 10 call me 4
quandam quack, as the public sees that my sal
taburas pills had more efcctual and powerful
operation on your system than all the medicine
you have taken these five years past for my sal
taburas pills, caused you TO quit the field of ac-
ton in short and dirty hurry, without second
appeal to the public or an apology for the con-
tcmptuous treatment you have given the public
by your endeavoring to impose u false assertion,
which you had to swallow as dog does his vom-
il. We had taken the shortc stand planest way
to prove that you was imposing on the public
with the most bare-faced falsehood, which we
put stop to, when we challenged you to call ON
any three, four or more of the respectable men
in this borough, and appoint your time, and we
would meet you face to face, and if you could
produce one receipt or settlement from the trus-
tees of st. Peters Church, for any sum of mo-
ney, even for one dollar from the commencement
of the drawing of the Lottery until this day, we
would acknowledge your assertion to be true
We gave you forty-eight hours to come forward:
you did not appear-neither could you in forty
relght years with the documents demanded, so
that you prove yourtelf to be II, for offering
such false assertions to the public. In your state
ment OF the sale OF the two first classes of the
lottery there is falsehood school boy may
with the glance of one eye, see; where you
state you sold the two first classes of the lottery
for $500 each, which sums made but $1,000; and
you tell the public you paid the church out of
the proceeds of these two classes the sum of
sl605 here Billy you prove yourself false again
Billy you hold the proceeds Of the lottery five
years. and finding your postulatums cannot be
any longer imposed on the public, nor your
pseudo account without day or date, be any long
er suffered to procrastnate your prolitarious i'm
PASSIONS as respects yourhonest actions respect.
ing the lottery in your farewell to the trustees
and your respected friend the quandam quack.
oh; we don't intend to take our leave of you,
dear Billy, as we have found your bond which
you passed to Governor Collins, which binds yo,


nthe penalty of ten thousand dollars to discharge
i the trust the church conhded in you. 1t isl
sble Billy as you now are in the possession O
this fact that it it was more convenient to you
you would prefer the trustees and the quandan
, were in Guinea. What did you do with the fou
iwrits you had marked out against the four trus

full articles.headline: From the Indiana Whig.
full articles.article:
CURE FOR THE BITE OF A SNAKE.


As the public in the western. country are
much interested in knowing whatever may
be \ good remedy for the poison elected in
to the human hesh by the bite of snake,
think it my duty to state fact within my
own knowledge.


About the year 1915 or 1916. one of my chill
dren was bitten by copperhead, on the
inside Of both ankles, nearly at the same in
stant. l instantly produced pulverized
charcoal, and mixed 1t with as much hogs
Lard rs made it adhere. I then made plas-
ter o. it, and applied it to the wounds,
renewing the plaster every twenty or thirty
minutes. for ten or twelve hours, at the
same time giving the child fresh milk to
drink. This remedy had the desired effect
and very little pain was endured after the
application. Not more than FIVE minutes {.
lspssd from the time the child was bitten un.

full articles.headline:
THE FARMER.

From the Farmers Assistant.
TRANSIT ANT1NG.
full articles.article:
In performing this operation, on all plants
Of wooden texture, the essential point is to
set the roots in the ground in situation SIM
liar to that in which they we're placed, be-
fore they were taken out; not only the same
depth. but, as Mr.. Forsyth says, with the
same side to the south which was the south
side before: But as they cannot be got out
of the ground nor set again into it, with their
full length Of roots, these must be cut off
to length proportionate to their size.-
Where they are very small, let them be cut
at the length of six or eight inches, and
where they are large, double that length
or more. Let them be carefully taken up,
without breaking the roots, cutting off those
that get broken, and cutting them all off at
their proper length; and let the hole, into
which they are to be set. be sufficiently
large to receive the roots without cramping
them: Then shake in the earth gently a.
bout them, so as that each one shall retain
its proper position. AS it is difficult to give
the fbrous roots their proper place, it is
generally best to cut most of these off. In
fruit trees, all the downright roots should be
cut off.


Ifthe roots have been some time out Of
ground, it is advisable to soak them in wa
ter for eight or ten hours before they are
set in. In cold or stiff soil, they should be
set shallower. than in warm mellow one.
After they are properly bedded in the
ground, a stake should be driven in near to
each one, leaning towards them, and to these
shey should each be tied, to keep them stea-
dy; and some mulch should be laid round
she roots OF each.


In transplanting the smaller kinds, a wet
time is to be chosen, and the evening is bet
ter than any other time. AS much of the
earth should be left round the roots as pos
sible, in taking them out of the ground; ant
il they are raised with a little instrument
called gardeners trowel, by which bunch
of earth can be raised with them, they viii
be the better for it. The holes where
they are set should be we'll watered, and tn,
water should previously be well warmed by
she sun.


For the times OF transplanting different
plants, and the distances they are to be SCI
apart, see the different articles which are
the subjects of this operation.
